page.title: 06SAND BAY AND SEA DEFENCES
page.content: Flooding from the sea has been a factor of life for the people living close to the shore at Kewstoke and Sand Bay. Worlebury Hill channels the frequent high winds and gales that are so prevalent in the area. December 1981 saw the most serious flooding and damage to property of this century. Many seaside properties suffered serious damage. After examining the alternatives it was decided to create a slope from the shoreline using sand and gravel that was to be dredged from the Bristol Channel. In the initial letter to the residents of the area the Wessex Water Authority indicated that 600,000 tons of sand and gravel would be required for the 2km stretch of beach. The work began in the middle of 1983 and completed by the end of January 1984.
